page.title: 01General Review
page.content: The River Yeo flows through the major part of this area,below the 15 metre contour line.This land is known as the moors or crouds.It is criss-crossed by drainage ditches known as rhynes. Access is by wide pathways called droves. The area is used for grazing cattle and sheep, and is cropped for silage and hay. 18th century Dutch drainage work made the moors accessable. Modern drainage and levelling has enabled cattle farming to be supplemented by sheep and cereal farming. There are 3 settlements:- Long Sutton, Long Load, Muchelney Ham. Long Sutton and Long Load are ribbon developments tracing the edge of the moors and carriage routes. Muchelney Ham is an agricultural site. Long Sutton was used by the Romans as an agricultural and military station.
